newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine clips wings of Russian military jets.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine clips wings of Russian military jets.

text.p: Ukraine slapped restrictions on Russian military aircraft flying in its airspace after unauthorised jets flew over the Black Sea during a recent NATO visit to Ukraine, a defene ministry official said on Thursday.

"Certain limits were imposed after some Russian aircraft flying over the Black Sea on March 25 and 26 violated rules governing the routes they were allowed to fly," a duty officer in the defene ministry press office told Reuters.

He gave no details about the restrictions or their duration, placed weeks before Russian President Boris Yeltsin is due to visit Ukraine -- a trip proposed and then called off at least six times in the past two years.

Ukrainian media, quoting unnamed defence officials, said the central Russia-based long-distance TU-22 military jets were flying spy missions in connection with a recent goodwill visit of NATO warships to the Ukrainian Black Sea port of Odessa.
"Russian planes must choose to follow international rules of aviation which require permission to fly certain air routes, in order to ensure safety in the air," the official said.
Ukraine, unlike Russia, is not opposed to eastward expansion of the western military alliance
In Moscow, officials in Russia's foreign ministry and air force confirmed that the restrictions were in place but declined to comment why they had been imposed.

Valery Yevnyevich, chief commander of the 6,000-strong Russian military base in the Dnestr region of Moldova bordering Ukraine, said its planes were trapped because of the new rules, Russia's Tass news agency reported.
Yeltsin promised last week to visit Ukraine in early June despite a long-running dispute between the two sides over division of the former Soviet Black Sea fleet.
